title: Data fetching
description: Nuxt provides composables to handle data fetching within your application.

children.value: Nuxt comes with two composables and a built-in library to perform data-fetching in browser or server environments:
is the most straightforward way to handle data fetching in a component setup function.
is great to make network requests based on user interaction.
share a common set of options and patterns that we will detail in the last sections.
Before that, it's imperative to know why these composables exist in the first place.
Why use specific composables for data fetching?
Nuxt is a framework which can run isomorphic (or universal) code in both server and client environments. If the

is used to perform data fetching in the setup function of a Vue component, this may cause data to be fetched twice, once on the server (to render the HTML) and once again on the client (when the HTML is hydrated). This is why Nuxt offers specific data fetching composables so data is fetched only once.
composables ensure that once an API call is made on the server, the data is properly forwarded to the client in the payload.
The payload is a JavaScript object accessible through
. It is used on the client to avoid refetching the same data when the code is executed in the browser
to inspect this data in the

component under the hood to prevent navigation before every async data is available to the view. The data fetching composables can help you leverage this feature and use what suits best on a per-calls basis.
to add a progress bar between page navigations.
composable is the most straightforward way to perform data fetching.

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
async function addTodo() {
  const todo = await $fetch('/api/todos', {
    method: 'POST',
    body: {
      // My todo data
    }
  })
}
</script>

children.value: network calls de-duplication and navigation prevention
for client-side interactions (event based) or combined with
when fetching the initial component data.
composable is responsible for wrapping async logic and returning the result once it is resolved.
It's developer experience sugar for the most common use case.
Watch a video from Alexander Lichter to dig deeper into the difference between
There are some cases when using the
composable is not appropriate, for example when a CMS or a third-party provide their own query layer. In this case, you can use
to wrap your calls and still keep the benefits provided by the composable.

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
const { data, error } = await useAsyncData('users', () => myGetFunction('users'))

// This is also possible:
const { data, error } = await useAsyncData(() => myGetFunction('users'))
</script>

children.value: is a unique key used to cache the response of the second argument, the querying function. This key can be ignored by directly passing the querying function, the key will be auto-generated.
Since the autogenerated key only takes into account the file and line where
is invoked, it is recommended to always create your own key to avoid unwanted behavior, like when you are creating your own custom composable wrapping
Setting a key can be useful to share the same data between components using

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
const { id } = useRoute().params

const { data, error } = await useAsyncData(`user:${id}`, () => {
  return myGetFunction('users', { id })
})
</script>

children.value: composable is a great way to wrap and wait for multiple
requests to be completed, and then process the results.

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
const { data: discounts, pending } = await useAsyncData('cart-discount', async () => {
  const [coupons, offers] = await Promise.all([
    $fetch('/cart/coupons'),
    $fetch('/cart/offers')
  ])

  return { coupons, offers }
})
// discounts.value.coupons
// discounts.value.offers
</script>

children.value: have the same return values listed below.
: the result of the asynchronous function that is passed in.
: a boolean indicating whether the data is still being fetched.
: a function that can be used to refresh the data returned by the
: a function that can be used to set
, and mark any currently pending requests as cancelled.
: an error object if the data fetching failed.
: a string indicating the status of the data request (

is finished before it can be executed again.
If you have not fetched data on the server (for example, with
be fetched until hydration completes. This means even if you await
return the same object type and accept a common set of options as their last argument. They can help you control the composables behavior, such as navigation blocking, caching or execution.

By default, data fetching composables will wait for the resolution of their asynchronous function before navigating to a new page by using Vueâ€™s Suspense. This feature can be ignored on client-side navigation with the
option. In that case, you will have to manually handle loading state using the

children.value: By default, data fetching composables will perform their asynchronous function on both client and server environments. Set the

to only perform the call on the client-side. On initial load, the data will not be fetched before hydration is complete so you have to handle a pending state, though on subsequent client-side navigation the data will be awaited before loading the page.
option, this can be useful for data that is not needed on the first render (for example, non-SEO sensitive data).

If you want to clear the data provided, for whatever reason, without needing to know the specific key to pass to

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
const { data, clear } = await useFetch('/api/users')

const route = useRoute()
watch(() => route.path, (path) => {
  if (path === '/') clear()
})
</script>

To re-run your fetching function each time other reactive values in your application change, use the
option. You can use it for one or multiple

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight twoslash lsp
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
const id = ref(1)

const { data, error, refresh } = await useFetch('/api/users', {
  /* Changing the id will trigger a refetch */
  watch: [id]
})
</script>

children.value:
Takes an inner value and returns a reactive and mutable ref object, which
has a single property
that points to the inner value.
- The object to wrap in the ref.

Fetch data from an API endpoint with an SSR-friendly composable.

/* Changing the id will trigger a refetch */
watching a reactive value won't change the URL fetched
. For example, this will keep fetching the same initial ID of the user because the URL is constructed at the moment the function is invoked.

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
const id = ref(1)

const { data, error, refresh } = await useFetch(`/api/users/${id.value}`, {
  watch: [id]
})
</script>

children.value: If you need to change the URL based on a reactive value, you may want to use a

Sometimes you may need to compute an URL from reactive values, and refresh the data each time these change. Instead of juggling your way around, you can attach each param as a reactive value. Nuxt will automatically use the reactive value and re-fetch each time it changes.

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
const id = ref(null)

const { data, pending } = useLazyFetch('/api/user', {
  query: {
    user_id: id
  }
})
</script>

children.value: In the case of more complex URL construction, you may use a callback as a
Every time a dependency changes, the data will be fetched using the newly constructed URL. Combine this with
, and you can wait until the reactive element changes before fetching.

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

children.value: when a fetch has started but not yet completed

in the browser, user headers like
will be directly sent to the API. But during server-side-rendering, since the
request takes place 'internally' within the server, it doesn't include the user's browser cookies, nor does it pass on cookies from the fetch response.
Pass Client Headers to the API
to access and proxy cookies to the API from server-side.
The example below adds the request headers to an isomorphic
call to ensure that the API endpoint has access to the same
header originally sent by the user.

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
const headers = useRequestHeaders(['cookie'])

const { data } = await useFetch('/api/me', { headers })
</script>

children.value: Be very careful before proxying headers to an external API and just include headers that you need. Not all headers are safe to be bypassed and might introduce unwanted behavior. Here is a list of common headers that are NOT to be proxied:
Pass Cookies From Server-side API Calls on SSR Response
If you want to pass on/proxy cookies in the other direction, from an internal request back to the client, you will need to handle this yourself.

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

children.value: /* Get the response from the server endpoint */
/* Get the cookies from the response */
/* Attach each cookie to our incoming Request */
/* Return the data of the response */

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
// This composable will automatically pass cookies to the client
const event = useRequestEvent()

const { data: result } = await useAsyncData(() => fetchWithCookie(event!, '/api/with-cookie'))

onMounted(() => console.log(document.cookie))
</script>

children.value: // This composable will automatically pass cookies to the client
Nuxt 3 provides a way to perform
fetching within the Options API. You must wrap your component definition within

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script>
export default defineNuxtComponent({
  /* Use the fetchKey option to provide a unique key */
  fetchKey: 'hello',
  async asyncData () {
    return {
      hello: await $fetch('/api/hello')
    }
  }
})
</script>

children.value: /* Use the fetchKey option to provide a unique key */
are the recommended way of declaring Vue components in Nuxt 3.
Serializing Data From Server to Client
to transfer data fetched on server to the client (as well as anything else that utilizes
. This allows us to transfer not just basic JSON but also to serialize and revive/deserialize more advanced kinds of data, such as regular expressions, Dates, Map and Set,
It is also possible to define your own serializer/deserializer for types that are not supported by Nuxt. You can read more in the
to data passed from your server routes when fetched with
- see the next section for more information.
directory, the response is serialized using
. However, since serialization is limited to only JavaScript primitive types, Nuxt does its best to convert the return type of

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
// Type of `data` is inferred as string even though we returned a Date object
const { data } = await useFetch('/api/foo')
</script>

children.value: // Type of `data` is inferred as string even though we returned a Date object
To customize the serialization behavior, you can define a
function on your returned object. If you define a
method, Nuxt will respect the return type of the function and will not try to convert the types.

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
// Type of `data` is inferred as
// {
//   createdAt: {
//     year: number
//     month: number
//     day: number
//   }
// }
const { data } = await useFetch('/api/bar')
</script>

children.value: Nuxt does not currently support an alternative serializer to
. However, you can return your payload as a normal string and utilize the
In the example below, we use

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

children.value: // Serialize the output to string, using superjson

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
import superjson from 'superjson'

// `date` is inferred as { createdAt: Date } and you can safely use the Date object methods
const { data } = await useFetch('/api/superjson', {
  transform: (value) => {
    return superjson.parse(value as unknown as string)
  },
})
</script>

children.value: // `date` is inferred as { createdAt: Date } and you can safely use the Date object methods
